Coronavirus outbreak: Passengers refuse to board flight with Wuhan travelers in 5-hour standoff

By Jackie Salo

  • View author archive
  • Get author RSS feed

1 Health care worker, 15 friends infected at Florida bar with different kind of Corona... 2 Brute accused of shoving elderly NYC woman is no stranger to jail 3 Brute ruthlessly knocks down elderly woman in random attack: video 4 Cops bust suspect who shoved elderly woman on NYC sidewalk 5 Motorist's wrong turn into enraged man's driveway nearly kills him

January 28, 2020 | 2:19pm | Updated January 28, 2020 | 8:31pm

Coronavirus

Donations to fight coronavirus, racial injustice could sustain charities

Passengers refused to board a plane to China Tuesday after realizing people from the city at the center of the coronavirus outbreak were also booked on the flight — leading to an hours-long standoff, according to reports.

More than 70 passengers refused to board the Chinese Southern Airlines plane in Nagoya, Japan, after recognizing the accents of 16 fellow travelers meant they came from Wuhan, where the deadly virus originated, the Sun reported, citing the Asian News Agency.

Wuhan has been on lockdown following the emergence of the mysterious illness last month, but millions of people had left the city before the quarantine began.

The passengers demanded the Wuhan travelers be barred from the flight to Shanghai — but eventually relented once staff from the Chinese consulate in Nagoya stepped in to mediate, the Daily Mail reported.

All of the passengers eventually boarded the plane, which landed five hours later than scheduled at Shanghai Pudong International Airport, the Sun reported.

Filed under china ,  Coronavirus ,  japan ,  1/28/20
